displayed_text: Family Member: Wow. Doctor: Yeah, the chemo class will sorta tell you a little bit about what’s more, like normal. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, you know, you’re gonna likely - you know seventy-five percent of people lose their hair on this. Family Member: So, is that - Doctor: And that tends to grow back Family Member: That class, is that here? Or is that a web cast? Doctor: No, it’s here. Family Member: It’s here. Patient: Any need for a driver - chemo days, things like that? Doctor: Yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: So, on chemo days, you have to have a driver. Ummm. You may not need him. But, I mean, my sense is that if you start getting sick and nauseated, and I have to give you a medicine that’s sedating - I don’t want you getting behind the wheel of a car and driving home.

Patient: No, he’s…I think he’s doing very well. Doctor: Yeah, me too. It was a nice article actually, very flattering. Family Member: Yes, yes. Patient: Yes. Doctor: Umm. Ehh. Nothing wrong with you other than your PSA’s going the wrong way. Patient: Yeah, I saw that. Doctor: Today’s is not bad. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: It might be an opportunity to put on a second drug on top of this current drug. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, you would stay on this, but we would pile on something else. Patient: Okay.

Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

Patient: And what is a PSMA? Doctor: That’s literally like a target. It’s like a PSA. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But it’s a target on your cells and we try to go after it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: That sounds like fun. Patient: Wow. Doctor: And you know in Europe it’s really been done for imaging. Like you really try to oh you do the PSMA scan so you’re trying to find where the cancer is. The struggle you know for us for the drug part is getting enough of a drug level to be able to kill the cell so Patient: Yeah. Doctor: that’s kind of like what this is. So I hope we get a spot but I already told M_____ to stick her foot out. Patient: But you know I mean I really have nothing to complain about because um it’s eleven and a half years since I was diagnosed. Doctor: That’s incredible. Patient: And um all things being considered I guess eleven and half a years ago I didn’t think I’d be here right now.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay. Alright. So remember we saw that your PSA had gone up. Family Member: It went up. Yes. Doctor: From four to nine. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: So because of that, I had asked for the scans. Okay? Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Now, on the scans, there was a little bit of growth in the lymph nodes. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Okay? The lymph nodes in your belly are getting slightly larger. So we are going to have to change your treatment and add different other treatments to this. Okay? Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So one of the treatments is a combination of a bone medication, it’s a radiation that goes to your bones, along with the immune therapy. Family Member: Okay. And that’s the injection he has?

Family Member: Sometimes, yeah. Doctor: No, my worry is that as we start chemo for the first few weeks of chemo until both of us figure out how you’re going to tolerate, how you’re going to do, maybe back off a little bit and take a break. Family Member: Back off on the - Doctor: And anyway, with the holidays maybe - Family Member: They did give him a set of exercises he can do – Doctor: Okay. Family Member: - at home. Doctor: Okay, yeah. Family Member: At home. Patient: Oh they’re stretching; they’re not - Doctor: Yeah, good, they’re not heavy-duty. Family Member: Yeah. Patient: No .No. No.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.4 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::4 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.agree: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::agree

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.neutral: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::neutral

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.College graduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::College graduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Um. It’s hard to say that because basically a bone scan is just about inflammation. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And so, if you had dental work or there’s inflammation from troubles related to the Xgeva. That would light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: You know, if it’s the cancer that’s really causing it, then that, that would cause it to light up. Patient: Okay. Doctor: I can’t tell ya. Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: You know, unless we stick a needle into the bone and say, “Does cancer come out?” Patient: Right. Doctor: Or is this just a hole there? And, so, part of me has to figure out from what you are saying is - is it better or not better. You know, what’s different? You know, clearly under here, I feel like a quarter. Patient: Mm, hmm.

Patient: We’re hoping you got the samples switched or something like that. Doctor: You know I was actually gonna check that and I haven’t done that. The big question is did anybody else have prostate surgery on the same day. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm, hmm. Doctor: Not by me, but it could be another doctor. Family Member: I would like to check it just for peace of mind only, but there’s nothing that would lead us to think it was all this and to be fifty to sixty percent involved with the prostate kind of blew our minds a little bit. Doctor: Me too. Yeah. Patient: It doesn’t add up. Family Member: It really doesn’t. It just doesn’t, so. Doctor: So, I forgot, I was actually gonna check that and I will, I forgot but I will do that. I have to figure out how to do that with the – either the operating room or the pathology department. Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: Maybe the operating room would be first to find out if – I can’t look up another patient’s record that doesn’t belong to me, - Patient: Right.

Patient: Mass. Doctor: Which we know because you had a biopsy in the past which proved that to be so. Patient: Mhmm, mhmm. Doctor: And uh the bone is not that clear whether there’s anything in there. To me it doesn’t look like there’s any cancer in there. Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: It looks like you have arthritis all the usual goodies that we’ve talked about, but mostly everything is here. Patient: You should have had uh, you should of had something here from where I had three broken ribs from a car wreck which I explained to the guy. You’re gonna see something there… Doctor: Yeah, yeah… Patient: …from a car wreck. Doctor: And it wasn’t even that that prominent. Patient: You’re gonna see stuff there. Doctor: You got that, I saw that, yep. So the good part is it’s, not the good part but, it’s primarily localized right here. So the question is what to do. Now one, I know you’ve asked about well why can’t we just go in and radiate or do some stuff there. Patient: It wasn’t quite that simplistic.

Patient: I had a CT scan Doctor: Yeah Patient: this morning and we asked for a stat read, but it… Doctor: Yeah. That’s the one. Patient: Okay. Wow. Doctor: Yeah, that’s what I’m reading Patient: That’s- They were really quick. Yeah. Doctor: Yeah. VIP apparently you are. Patient: Well, probably. Doctor: Well we said we just really need to know. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: You know so we’re we’re doing the whole we gotta come up with the next study uhh situa - and the good part is there’s more trials that opened up. Patient: Yeah.

Family Member: Does that lead you to believe there’s more there still if it’s higher? Doctor: Yeah then one would think it’s in another part of your body like in the bones or something like that. Family Member: Um hum, um hum. That’s what I worry about too. Doctor: Um the question arose about getting scans on you? Patient: Mm, hmm. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Mm,hmm. Doctor: So we (pause) Patient: Okay. Doctor: If the PSA is anything significant Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: Then maybe we would get scans just to have that knowledge. A CT scan and bone scan. Patient: Right.

Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?

Patient: Okay. Doctor: We have to sort it out by tomorrow because it’s you know technically Monday’s not a holiday but most people are taking off. Patient: Well I’m thinking it’s Tuesday. Doctor: Yeah that’s why I’m saying it’s got to be a week because you’ve got to fourth and the third is mostly a lot of people are off. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So that leaves basically Friday and Wednesday. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So okay. Real good. Family Member: Okay for M__ Patient: Anything else that I haven’t asked you?
DOC No. I’ll tell you what’s amazing. You look as good as you did even when we were having a bunch of these issues so that’s really a testament to you. That’s amazing. Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: I mean you are, you know there’s a lot of stuff in there you got treated but you actually, you never looked bad and you look great, but you always look great so that makes me super happy. It really does. Patient: Yeah.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay your testosterone is not as low as I would like it. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s it’s low, but it should be lower ideally with the Lupron. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So your next Lupron which is tomorrow is happening with R____. Patient: Right… Doctor: Right? Patient: …and after that you guys are supposed to take it over. Doctor: Okay, alright we’ll do that. Patient: I don’t ever see Dr. R____ no more over there. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Are we giving you a couple alternatives? Doctor: Yeah give me a couple options. Patient: Thursday this week and uh… Family Member: Monday? Patient: No No Tuesday next week. Doctor: Tuesday, good. That works out because then Tuesday I’ll be there too if you have any questions about the consent if anything comes up. So we’ll try for this week Thursday or Tuesday next week. Patient: Yeah. Thursday afternoon. Doctor: Afternoon, sorry. Got it. Family Member: So let’s – okay so that happens. Then what happens next? Doctor: So at that point if everything is looking good we will also be scheduling the biopsy and then the treatment date after that. Patient: And when do I start on the BET? Doctor: So the…
